sect2.title: TIE_ALREADY_DECL
sect2.para: Duplicate variable declaration. For example, multiple declarations of the same argument in a list (such as iclass operands) will generate this error.

sect2.title: TIE_ALREADY_DEFINED
sect2.para: Duplicate definition of a TIE variable. All variables in the same scope must have unique names. For example, two states cannot be defined with the same name.

sect2.title: TIE_ASSERT_FAILURE
sect2.para: This error means that an assertion has failed in TC. We ask that you contact Tensilica support and send us the resulting archive result.tgz which can be found in your TDK directory. This will enable us to debug the problem, and hopefully resolve it in a timely manner.

Please try to rewrite the TIE that caused this internal error in TC. Most times a line number and a filename of the TIE that caused the error was printed along with the error message.Try first to rewrite this TIE.

sect2.title: TIE_ASSIGNMENT_WIDTH_MISMATCH
sect2.para: The bit width of RHS and LHS in an assignment are not the same. This indicates that there may be some truncation in the result, or in some cases undesirable zero extension in the result. This warning is not reported by default. To see it, you have to turn on the option -warnall, or activate this specific warning with the flag -warn TIE_ASSIGNMENT_WIDTH_MISMATCH
Example of warning:
sect2.verbatim: wire [31:0] a, b; wire [7:0] c = a | b;
sect2.para: This will generate a warning that the RHS of the assignment is 32 bits and the LHS is 8 bits. The correct way to write the code is
sect2.verbatim: wire [31:0] tmp = a|b; wire [7:0] c = tmp[7:0];

sect2.title: TIE_BUFFER_OVERFLOW
sect2.para: TIE compiler will not accept a single line of more than 6K characters. If a single line that is longer than 6K characters is found, it generates this error.

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_ARG_ID
sect2.para: When using TIEcomp, inputs of the TIEcomp module should be assigned directly from variables in the current scope, and outputs of the TIEcomp module should be assigned directly to variables in the current scope. Any error is reported with this error code.
For example, when using the operation BAR as a TIEcomp, an error is generated as shown
sect2.verbatim: operation BAR { inout AR ars, in AR simm8 }
TIEcomp(BAR, { ars = a, simm8 = b }, { a = ars + 2, c = ars } );
sect2.para: Error: (TIE_COMPMOD_ARG_ID), Each entry of the computation module's output argument list must specify an identifier on the right-hand side of the assignment. The identifier must specify an argument from the "BAR" operation.

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_ILLEGAL_ARG
sect2.para: When using TIEcomp, assignments to and from variables that are not inputs or outputs of the TIEcomp module are reported with this error. For example, when using the operation BAR as a TIEcomp, the following code will generate an error as shown
sect2.verbatim: operation BAR { inout AR ars, in AR simm8 }
TIEcomp(BAR, { ars = a, simm8 = b }, { a = ars, c = arr } );
sect2.para: Error: (TIE_COMPMOD_ILLEGAL_ARG), The computation module's output argument list specifies an argument, "arr", that is not an argument to the "BAR" operation.

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_ILLEGAL_INS
sect2.para: Some Xtensa opcodes are not allowed to be used as TIEcomp, and when used as TIEcomp generates this error. For example, the following code will generate an error as shown
TIEcomp(CALLX, {ars = a}, {t = arr});
Error: (TIE_COMPMOD_ILLEGAL_INS), Instruction "CALLX" is not allowed in computation module.

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_MISSING_ARG
sect2.para: When using TIEcomp, if any input of the TIEcomp module is not assigned, or if an output of the TIEcomp module is not used, you will get this error. For example, when using the operation BAR as a TIEcomp, the following code will generate an error as shown
sect2.verbatim: operation BAR { inout AR ars, in AR simm8 }
sect2.para: Error: (TIE_COMPMOD_MISSING_ARG), The computation module's input argument list is missing an assignment to argument "simm8" of operation "BAR".

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_RECURSION
sect2.para: The TIEcomp invocation in an operation directly or indirectly calls the same operation recursively.

sect2.title: TIE_COMPMOD_INVOKE
sect2.para: TIEcomp modules can be instantiated only in operation or reference. Instantiating a TIEcomp module in a semantic or function will generate this error.

sect2.title: TIE_CONFIG_COPROCESSOR_COUNT
sect2.para: The tie description requires a coprocessor count that is not specified in the Xtensa Config description. If you get this error, you will have to rebuild your Xtensa configuration with the correct number of coprocessors.

sect2.title: TIE_CONFIG_PIF_WIDTH
sect2.para: The memory width required by the tie description cannot be accommodated by the Xtensa processor configuration selected. For example, if you have a 128 bit register file, the load and store operations for the register file will require a 128 bit memory interface in the base processor and if the Xtensa config has a memory interface of 32 or 64 bits, you will get this error.

sect2.title: TIE_CONSTANT_DECIMAL_OVERFLOW
sect2.para: The integer constant value cannot be represented in 32 bits, causing overflow.

sect2.title: TIE_CONSTANT_FORMAT
sect2.para: An illegal format is used for a sized constant, e.g. 32'bff, since the binary format b can only have 0 and 1.

sect2.title: TIE_CONSTANT_ILLEGAL_SIZE
sect2.para: The number of bits specified in a sized constant is illegal, e.g. 0'd3.

sect2.title: TIE_CONSTANT_ILLEGAL_VALUE
sect2.para: The value of a sized constant contains illegal characters, e.g 32'hYZ.

sect2.title: TIE_CONSTANT_VALUE_OVERFLOW
sect2.para: The constant number cannot be represented in the number of bits specified, eg. 4'd25.

sect2.title: TIE_CONTEXT_SWITCH_EXPENSIVE
sect2.para: In configurations supporting real time operation systems. It is recommended that all states and register files are put in a coprocessor in order to reduce the context switch overhead. This warning message is generated when the estimated context switch overhead is too large.

sect2.title: TIE_COPROC_MULTI_DEF
sect2.para: Coprocessors with the same name are defined multiple times in the TIE file. However, they are not assgined to the same coprocessor number.

sect2.title: TIE_COPROC_MAX_NUMBER
sect2.para: The coprocessor number used exceeds the maximum of 8 coprocessors allowed.

sect2.title: TIE_COPROC_NUM_ILLEGAL
sect2.para: The coprocessor number must be between 0 and 7. It is not necessary to define a coprocessor with a number. If no number is assigned, the tie compiler will automatically assign a number to the coprocessor.

sect2.title: TIE_COPROC_NUM_USED
sect2.para: The coprocessor number is already used by another coprocessor. It is not necessary to define a coprocessor with a number. If no number is assigned, the tie compiler will automatically assign a number to the coprocessor.

sect2.title: TIE_COPROC_UNMAPPED_STATE
sect2.para: The coprocessor includes a TIE state that is not mapped to programmer visible user registers, which indicates that these states cannot be saved and restored when Xtensa processor switches context to using a different coprocessor.

sect2.title: TIE_CORE_INSTRUCTION
sect2.para: Warning Level = 0 (Not suppressed by default)

sect2.title: TIE_CORE_NAME_DUP
sect2.para: The variable is trying to redefine a previously declared variable in the Xtensa core description. Note that this checking is done in a case sensitive way. For example, the following tie will generate an error
field S slot0[19:16]
Error: (TIE_CORE_NAME_DUP), User tie type FIELD "S" is trying to redefine Xtensa core type FIELD "s" which is illegal. Names of the same type must be unique and cannot differ only in case.

sect2.title: TIE_CSTUB_SWAP_CONCAT_INTF
sect2.para: In cstub_swap construct, the concatenation must be a memory interface. That is, it must be one of the following interfaces: MemDataIn8, MemDataIn16, MemDataIn32, MemDataIn64, MemDataIn128, MemDataOut8, MemDataOut16, MemDataOut32, MemDataOut64, MemDataOut128
The interface must also be in the iclass of the corresponding instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_CSTUB_SWAP_CONCAT_INTEGER
sect2.para: In cstub_swap construct, the concatenation must span the entire interface. It is not allowed to overlap any bit in the interface, nor is allowed to neglect any bit.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ALIGNMENT_LT_SIZE
sect2.para: The alignment for the ctype is less than the size of the ctype. Load/store operations to read and write these ctypes from memory to register cannot be automatically generated by the tie compiler.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ALREADY_DEFINED
sect2.para: The ctype is already defined. Note that a ctype can be automatically generated by the tie compiler from a register file.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_COUNT
sect2.para: A structural ctype must contain more than one field.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_CTYPE_CASE
sect2.para: For a structural ctype that contains more than one register, the types of each of its fields must be a valid ctype. The TIE compiler did not find a valid ctype, but did find a similar one.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_DUP_NAME
sect2.para: Two fields in a ctype must not have conflicting field names. Two field names conflict if they are the same under a case-insensitive comparison.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_INVALID_CTYPE
sect2.para: For a structural ctype that contains more than one register, the types of each of its fields must be a valid ctype.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_INVALID_NAME
sect2.para: The name of ctype fields must not contain a '.' or be a C/C++ keyword.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_FIELD_NESTED
sect2.para: Structural ctypes must only contain ctypes that reference non-structural ctypes.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_GENERATED_DEFAULT
sect2.para: When a register file has two or more ctypes associated with it, one of them is selected to be the default ctype for that register file. You can explicitly select this by using the keyword default on the line that declares the ctype. If a default ctype is not specified in the TIE description, the TIE compiler automatically chooses one as the default. It is recommended that you always explicitly specify the default ctype for register files with more than one ctype.

When a register file has more than one ctype associated with it, every instruction with one or more operands from the register file needs an instruction prototype. The instruction prototype specifies the ctype(s) associated with that instruction. If the instruction prototype is not specified in the TIE description, it is automatically generated by the TIE compiler using the default ctype as the ctype for every operand of the register file.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_ALIGNMENT
sect2.para: The alignment specification of a ctype must be a multiple of 8 bits (a byte), not greater than 128 and must be a power of 2.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_DEFAULT
sect2.para: The size of a default ctype must be greater than or equal to the regfile entry size.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_DEFAULT_FIELD
sect2.para: The default ctype for a register file must map to a single register or view.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_SIZE
sect2.para: The size of the ctype must be less than or equal to the width of the register file in which the ctype belongs. For example, the following tie will generate a warning
regfile XR 18 4 xr ctype xrtype 24 32 XR
Warning: (TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_SIZE), Ctype xrtype has size 24 which is greater then the size of the containing regfile. It is recommended that the ctype's size be made <= to the regfile size.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_ILLEGAL_NAME
sect2.para: Ctype names cannot have the character dot in them, since this will cause illegal C code.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_NO_FIELD_PROTOS
sect2.para: The TIE compiler does not automatically generate protos for ctypes with fields.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_NO_PREDEFINED
sect2.para: Xtensa core register files such as AR cannot have user defined ctypes.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_NO_REGFILE
sect2.para: The register file used by the ctype is not found in the tie description.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_REGFILE_CONFLICT
sect2.para: The ctype name has a conflict with another register file name which the ctype does not belong to. A ctype can have the same name as the register file which it occupies.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_SIZE_GT_PIF
sect2.para: The size of the ctype is greater than the memory access width of the Xtensa configuration selected. This means that reading or writing the ctype from memory will involve multiple load or store instructions. Tie compiler cannot automatically generate such instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_SIZE_GT_STORE
sect2.para: Store instructions cannot be automatically generated by tie compiler for this ctype. This could be because the size of the ctype being greater than memory access width of the Xtensa configuration selected, or the Xtensa configuration not allowing stores of this size due to hardware restrictions.

sect2.title: TIE_CTYPE_SIZE_LT_REGFILE
sect2.para: The size of the ctype is smaller than the width of the register file it occupies. This means that when reading or writing the ctype from memory, the unoccupied bits will have to be set, either by zero extension or sign extension, or any other algorithm. Load/Store instructions cannot be automatically generated by tie compiler for this ctype.

sect2.title: TIE_DECODING_DUP_BIT
sect2.para: The same bits in the instruction word is used more than once for decoding a format or instruction. For example, the following tie description will generate an error
format xl64 64 { slot0, slot1 } { InstBuf[2] == 1'b1 && InstBuf[2:0]== 3'd7 }
Error: (TIE_DECODING_DUP_BIT), Bit InstBuf[2] is used multiple times in the decoding expression

sect2.title: TIE_DUP_VAR
sect2.para: Duplicate variable name within a scope. For example, in the following code, the operation TESTDUP reads a state called TESTDUP and generates an error because in the body of the operation "TESTDUP" can be the state name or the opcode name.
state TESTDUP 32 add_read_write operation TESTDUP { out AR a } { in TESTDUP } { assign a = TESTDUP;}
Error: (TIE_DUP_VAR), In reference TESTDUP, the variable TESTDUP can be either STATE or OPCODE.

sect2.title: TIE_EMPTY
sect2.para: Empty tie description.

sect2.title: TIE_ENCODING_FLIX_USED
sect2.para: If the automatic instruction encoding uses bits in the instruction word that are designated to FLIX length and format encoding, then this warning is generated to make the user aware that the output of this tie cannot be extended to add FLIX in future. The relevant bits are the "op0" bits, which occupy InstBuf[3:0] and InstBuf[63:60] in a LittleEndian and BigEndian configuration respectively.

sect2.title: TIE_ENCODING_FP_USED
sect2.para: If the automatic instruction encoding uses bits in the instruction word that are designated to the Floating point unit of Xtensa, this warning is generated to make the user aware that the output of this tie cannot be added to a Xtensa processor with the FPU.

sect2.title: TIE_ENCODING_MAC
sect2.para: If the automatic instruction encoding uses bits in the instruction word that are designated to the MAC16 unit of Xtensa, this warning is generated to make the user aware that the output of this tie cannot be added to a Xtensa processor with the MAC16 unit.

sect2.title: TIE_ENCODING_RECURSIVE
sect2.para: The encoding of an opcode references an opcode whose encoding reference the first opcode, causing a recursive encoding.

sect2.title: TIE_ENCODING_USED
sect2.para: If the automatic instruction encoding uses bits in the instruction word that are designated to a specific architectural option in the Xtensa processor, this warning is generated to make the user aware that the output of this tie cannot be added to a Xtensa processor with that architectural option. For example, tie compiler may use the Density instruction space Xtensa for encoding the operations if the Xtensa configuration used does not have the Density instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_EXPRESSION_WIDTH_MISMATCH
sect2.para: This warning is seen only when TIE compiler is run with the option -warnall. It is suppressed by default.

According to TIE bit-width rules, which follow Verilog, a context-determined expression is one where the bit-width of the expression depends on its parent expression. In this case, the expression has a "required-width" that is determined by the parent expression, as well as the "computed-width". If the required-width is different from the computed width, the expression and its operands will be truncated or zero-extended as appropriate. If this is undesirable, the user can run TIE compiler with the -warnall flag to see the mismatches. The warning indicates that the computed width of an expression or the width of a variable in an expression is not the same as the required width of that expression or variable. Please refer to the Computation Section of the TIE Language Reference Manual for further details of bit-width rules.

sect2.title: TIE_EXPRESSION_OPERAND_MISMATCH
sect2.para: This warning is seen only when TIE compiler is run with the option -warnall. It is suppressed by default.

According to TIE bit-width rules, which follow Verilog, if the operands of an operation have a "required-width", then the operands are zero-extended or truncated as appropriate. If this is not desirable, then the user can run the TIE compiler with the -warnall flag to see where the operands of an operation are mismatched. Please refer to the Computation Section of the TIE Language Reference Manual for further details of bit-width rules.
This warning indicates that the two operands of an operation have different bit width, and one of them will be zero extended. For example, the following code will generate a warning as shown.
Warning: (TIE_EXPRESSION_OPERAND_MISMATCH), Operands of arithmetic operation must have the same size, however the operand "a" is 4 bits and operand "b" is 5 bits

sect2.title: TIE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED
sect2.para: If the Xtensa configuration or release of TIE compiler does not support the feature in the tie description, this error is generated.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_CORE_DIFF_WIDTH
sect2.para: A predefined field in Xtensa core is redefined with a different width. Xtensa core fields (such as "s", "r", "t") can be redefined in user slots in FLIX, but they have to be the same length.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_DIFF_WIDTH
sect2.para: A field can be defined more than once. In fact a field has to be defined in every slot of a FLIX format where it is used for an opcode encoding. However, the width of the field must be the same in all definitions. The following is illegal because the bit width of the field "fldx" is 7 bits in slot0 and 8 bits in slot1.
field fldx slot0[10:4] field fldx slot1[7:0]

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_INDEX_ORDER
sect2.para: Incorrect indexing of a field. The only indexing allowed is field[ from:to ], where from is >= to.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_INDEX_RANGE
sect2.para: Incorrect indexing of a field[from:to], either one of the indices is beyond the width of the field.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_MULTI_DEF
sect2.para: A field can be defined more than once. In fact a field has to be defined in every slot of a FLIX format where it is used for an opcode encoding. However, it cannot be defined more than once in the same slot.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_NO_SLOT
sect2.para: Field is not defined in any slot.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_OVERLAP_BITS
sect2.para: Definition of a field uses specific bits of a slot more than once. For example, in the following code, the field definition of "rts" uses the bit s[2] more than once.
field rts {r,s[2:0], t, s[3:2]}

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_SLOT_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Field names and slot names must be unique in a case-sensitive way. This is to avoid duplicate variable names generated by TIE compiler in software libraries. For example, a field name "SLOTa" and a slot name "slota" will be illegal.

sect2.title: TIE_FIELD_TOO_LARGE
sect2.para: The field width is bigger than the slot it occupies.

sect2.title: TIE_FILE_READ_FAIL
sect2.para: TIE compiler could not read the tie file.

sect2.title: TIE_FILE_WRITE_FAIL
sect2.para: TIE compiler could not write a file to generate the tdk.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_ALREADY_DEFINED
sect2.para: A format with the same name as already been defined.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_COUNT
sect2.para: The maximum number of formats allowed is 7.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_FORMAT_OVERLAP
sect2.para: The decoding logic of two formats overlap. For example, in the following code (assuming a 64 bit instruction word in a little Endian configuration), the decoding logic for "xl64" and "m64" are overlapping because they are both the default decoding logic for length len64.
length len64 64 { InstBuf[3:0] == 15 }
format x64 len64 { slot0, slot1 } format m64 len64 { slot2 }
slot slot0 x64 [29:4] slot slot1 x64 [63:30] slot slot2 m64 [27:4]

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_INSTR_CONNECT_LIMIT
sect2.para: The total number of connected groups of operations in a format exceeds the limit 15. A group of operations is all operations that share the same slots in the format. For example:
operation FOO and BAR are in the same group, because they are only defined in slot0. operation TEE is not in the same group as operation FOO and BAR, because it is also defined in slot3.

Two groups of operations are considered connected if they have at least one slot in common. In the above example, operations FOO and BAR are connected to operation TEE, because they are all defined in slot0. However, operation KII is not connected to either operations FOO/BAR and operation TEE, because they do not have one slot in common.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_LENGTH_DISJOINT
sect2.para: A format and the length of the format have conflicting decoding logic. For example, in the following code, the format "x64" defines a decoding logic of "InstBuf[3] == 1'b0", but the length "len64" which it uses has the decoding logic of "InstBuf[3:0] == 4'b1111" which means InstBuf[3] has a conflict.
length len64 64 {InstBuf[3:0] == 4'b1111} format x64 len64 { slot0, slot1 } {InstBuf[3] == 1'b0"}

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_DISJOINT
sect2.para: The bits used by the decoding logic of a format are also being used by a slot in the format. For example, in the following code, InstBuf[4] is being used for decoding the format x64. The slot "slot1" as defined here also occupies bit InstBuf[4].

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_OVERLAP_SLOTS
sect2.para: Slots in a format overlap. For example, in the following code, both the slots "slot0" and "slot1" occupy InstBuf[29].
length len64 64 {InstBuf[3:0] == 4'b1111}
format x64 len64 { slot0, slot1 }
slot slot0 x64 [29:4] slot slot1 x64 [63:29]

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_COUNT
sect2.para: TC restricts the number of slots in one format to 8.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_MAX_SLOT_COUNT
sect2.para: XCC compiler restricts the total number of slots to 64.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_NOT_DEFINED
sect2.para: Slot referred in the format statement has not been defined.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_NOT_SPECIFIED
sect2.para: All slots in a format must be specified in the format definition to specify the ordering of slots in the assembly code.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_OPCODE_ENCODING
sect2.para: The encoding of an opcode in a slot uses a field that overlaps with the decoding bits for the format to which the slot belongs to. This is legal as long as the encoding specified assigns the overlapping bits to the same value, in which case the same bits will be used for decoding the format as well as an opcode in the format. However, it is illegal to assign the bits to different values, or to use the bits used for decoding for an operand.

For example, in the following code, the slot "slot0" occupies "InstBuf[31:0]", and field "op0A" which is defined as "slot0[7:4]" occupies "InstBuf[7:4]". The encoding of opcode "MYOP" assigns bits "InstBuf[7:4] = 4'b0000", which conflicts with the decoding of the format, which assigns "InstBuf[4] = 1'b1". Note that encoding of "MYOP" as "op0A=4'0001" would be legal.
length len64 64 {InstBuf[3:0] == 4'b1111}
format x64 len64 { slot0, slot1 } { InstBuf[4] == 1'b1 }
slot slot0 x64[31:0] slot slot1 x64[63:32]
field op0A slot0[7:4] opcode MYOP op0A=4'b0000

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_SLOT_ILLEGAL
sect2.para: A FLIX format cannot use Xtensa core slot "Inst" directly. User is required to create his/her own slots and add Xtensa Core opcodes that are allowed to be in FLIX to the slots.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_WRONG_DECODER
sect2.para: Legal decoding expressions for decoding formats are restricted to the form
InstBuf[from:to] == <constant> [ && InstBuf[from:to] == <constant> ]
This is to ensure that the decoding logic can meet the timing constraints for decoding the instruction. Decoding logic should not have arbitrary amount of logic.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_NO_DECODER
sect2.para: If there are multiple formats in FLIX, each format needs to have a decoding expression using some of the bits in the instruction word. TIE compiler can generate the encoding automatically if there are bits available. However, if the slots in a format leave no bits for encoding a format, it is an error. For example, in the following code, there are no bits to encode format "x64", because the slots "slot0" and "slot1" occupy all the bits.
slot slot0 x64 [31:4] slot slot1 x64 [63:32]

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_NO_LENGTH
sect2.para: Each length has to be decoded in FLIX. The only bits allowed to be used for decoding length are InstBuf[3:0] in LittleEndian or InstBuf[63:60] in BigEndian Xtensa configurations respectively. Furthermore, the only encoding space available for length are the values "4'd14" and "4'd15" for these bits. Therefore, a maximum of two length specifications can be encoded. Also, these encoding values should not conflict with opcode encodings if the same bits are used for a slot.
If TIE compiler is unable to generate a decoding for the length specified in the format within these bits due to lack of encoding space, then this error is generated.

sect2.title: TIE_FORMAT_LENGTH_OVERLAP
sect2.para: Each length has to be decoded in FLIX. The only bits allowed to be used for decoding length are InstBuf[3:0] in LittleEndian or InstBuf[63:60] in BigEndian Xtensa configurations respectively. Furthermore, the only encoding space available for length are the values "4'd14" and "4'd15" for these bits. Therefore, a maximum of two length specifications can be encoded. Also, these encoding values should not conflict with opcode encodings if the same bits are used for a slot.
If TIE compiler is unable to generate a decoding for the length specified in the format within these bits due to slots in the format overlapping these bits, then this error is generated.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_ALREADY_DECLARED
sect2.para: A function with the same name has been already declared.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_INPUT_ARG
sect2.para: Number of arguments in a TIE function call does not match the number of function inputs.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_INTERNAL_NAME
sect2.para: A TIE function cannot have the same name as a TIE module.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_IO_NAME
sect2.para: Duplicate input/output name found in a function declaration. All inputs and outputs must be unique. The function name is also the output name.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_RECURSIVE
sect2.para: A TIE function recursively calls the same function, either directly or by instantiating another function.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_SHARED
sect2.para: A TIE function cannot instantiate a shared function. Shared functions can only be called from an instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_UNUSED
sect2.para: A TIE function is defined but not used. No hardware is generated for this.

sect2.title: TIE_FUNCTION_IO_DECL
sect2.para: Illegal function input/output declaration. Legal syntax for function declaration is

sect2.title: TIE_FUTURE_VERSION
sect2.para: The variable name is a keyword in a future version of TIE language. It is preferable to use a different name so that when upgrading to the next version of TIE language, the tie description will work without modification. For example, the name "queue" is a keyword in LX version and should be avoided as a variable name even if not using LX at this time.

sect2.title: TIE_GENERATE
sect2.para: TIE compiler automatically generates opcode encodings and operands from operation and register file descriptions. Any error in this process is reported as TIE_GENERATE with a unique message that explains the problem encountered. Common errors are:

item.itemtext: no encoding space found for encoding the opcodes
operations to load/store register file could not be generated
operation arguments could not be coalesced to operands as specified due to constraints such as a combined semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_GENERATED_OPERATION
sect2.para: TIE compiler will report all the operations it automatically generated.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_ARG_MULTIPLE_DECL
sect2.para: Same argument is declared more than once in an iclass.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_COND_KILL
sect2.para: If an instruction has a conditional kill on an output operand/state, all instructions that share the iclass must also have conditional kill. This is to avoid the compiler incorrectly inferring the instruction without the conditional kill as read-modify-write.
For example, the following is illegal. You have to put MYMOVE and MYCONDMOVE in different iclasses.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_CORE_ICLASS
sect2.para: The iclass name conflicts with a predefined iclass in the Xtensa core.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_CORE_OPERAND
sect2.para: The operand is an Xtensa core operand that cannot be used by user TIE.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_CORE_STATE
sect2.para: The state is an Xtensa core state that cannot be used by user TIE.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_DIFF_SLOT
sect2.para: For an opcode to belong to a slot, all fields required for encoding the opcode and operands must be declared in the slot.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_DUPLICATE_OPCODE
sect2.para: Opcode name is declared more than once in a iclass.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_IMM_OPERAND_DIR
sect2.para: Immediate ranges/operands, fields and tables can only be declared as inputs.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_INTERFACE_DIR
sect2.para: The direction of the interface in the iclass/operation does not match the direction in the definition of the interface. For example, the memory address interface "VAddr" can only be declared as an "out".

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_LOADBYTEDISABLE
sect2.para: The interface LoadByteDisable is used for arbitrary byte enables for loads and can be used only for load operations (using MemDatIn).

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_MEMDATA
sect2.para: An operation can only do a load (using MemDataIn*) or a store (using MemDataOut*) The same operation cannot do a load and a store. This is illegal in the current Xtensa architecture.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_MEMDATAIN
sect2.para: An operation can use only one size of load data (MemDataIn). Legal values of MemDataIn are 8,16,32,64 and 128. The legal values also depend on the data memory width of the Xtensa processor core.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_MEMDATAOUT
sect2.para: An operation can use only one size of store data (MemDataOut). Legal values of MemDataOutIn are 8,16,32,64 and 128. The legal values also depend on the data memory width of the Xtensa processor core.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_NO_MEMDATA
sect2.para: Load/Store operations must use the interfaces VAddr and MemDataIn/Out interfaces together. These interfaces cannot be used independently.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_NO_VADDR
sect2.para: Load/Store operations must use the interfaces VAddr and MemDataIn/Out interfaces together. These interfaces cannot be used independently.

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_OPERAND_NUM
sect2.para: XCC compiler restricts the number of operands in an operation to 512. Operands include all input/output arguments, states and interfaces (including tie ports).

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_OPERAND_REGFILE_NUM
sect2.para: The total number of inputs/output read and written from an instruction to a register file must not exceed the number of entries in the register file. For example, if a register file has 4 entries, an operation cannot declare more than 4 operands (inputs + output) from the register file,

sect2.title: TIE_ICLASS_STOREBYTEDISABLE
sect2.para: The interface StoreByteDisable is used for arbitrary byte enables for stores and can be used only for store operations (using MemDataOut).

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_CONST
sect2.para: If a constant definition has "X" in it, these will be converted to "0". This warning is suppressed by default. Run TIE compiler with flag -warnall to see it.

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_COPROC
sect2.para: Coprocessor includes undefined states or register files.

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_ID
sect2.para: Valid names in TIE language must contain valid alphanumeric characters. Names cannot start or end with "_" or ".". Names cannot also start with "TIE_".

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_IMM_OPERAND
sect2.para: Illegal immediate operand description. Immediate operands must have the description
operand name field_name decoding_expression encoding_expression
decoding expression must only use the operand name and table name encoding expression must only use the field name and table name

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_INTEGER
sect2.para: The integer value specified is incorrect. For example, in an immediate range specification, the integer value for the step size must be a power-of-2, and the lower and upper values must be a multiple of the step size. Following are some examples of illegal code
immediate_range ir1 0 255 3 immediate_range ir3 0 255 2

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_LHS_ASSIGNMENT
sect2.para: The left hand side of an assignment can only be a variable name or a concatenation of two variables.

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_RANGE
sect2.para: Immediate range low value must be less than high value

sect2.title: TIE_ILLGAL_RANGE_VALUE
sect2.para: Immediate range low and high value must be valid integers

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_REG_OPERAND

item.itemtext: using 0 or more than one register file name in decoding
using 0 or more than one field name in decoding
field used in decoding is not the same as the field used in declaration
field used to index the register file has more bits than needed (warning)
using an encoding expression, which is illegal for register operand
using an illegal variable name in decoding

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_REPLICATION
sect2.para: Replication must have an integer amount that is > 0.

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_SYNTAX
sect2.para: Syntax Error.

sect2.title: TIE_ILLEGAL_COMPMOD
sect2.para: A TIEcomp module must be a valid operation or an instruction with a reference.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_ARG_DIR
sect2.para: The direction of the first appearance of an IMAP argument must match the direction that is declared in the argument list. If the argument is declared as direction in, the first appearance of the argument needs to be an in or inout operand of an instruction. If the argument is declared as out, its first appearance needs to be an out operand of an instruction. If the argument is declared as inout, its first appearance needs to be an in or inout operand of an instruction. Please note the first appearance of a temporary needs to be of an out operand type.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_ARG_DUP
sect2.para: The same name appear multiple times in IMAP argument or temporary list.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_ARG_NO_POINTER
sect2.para: No pointer type is allowed in IMAP argument list, please use AR type instead.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_ARG_UNKNOWN
sect2.para: An argument or temporary has an unknown type.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_CODEARG_NUM
sect2.para: The number of argument listed in IMAP code is different from the number of argument of the iclass of the corresponding instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_CODEARG_REGFILE
sect2.para: IMAP code argument accesses a different register file from the one specified in the corresponding iclass.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_CODEARG_TYPE
sect2.para: IMAP code argument has a different type from the one specified in the corresponding iclass.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_CODEARG_UNKNOWN
sect2.para: An implementation or pattern code argument cannot be found in the argument or temporary list.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_COPY_DEST_TYPE
sect2.para: The destination of a pseudo-copy instruction needs to be of register type.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_CYCLIC_MAP
sect2.para: If the input pattern of the imap only contains one instruction, the number of operands of the instruction in the input pattern must be greater than the number of operands in the instruction in the output pattern. The method to calculate the number of operands is as follows: input and output operands are counted as one; inout operands are counted as two.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_IMMD
sect2.para: Immediate operands can only be used once in the implementation/pattern. It is a restriction of the current release.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_INVALID_OPCODE
sect2.para: The opcode is not a defined Xtensa ISA instruction, nor a user TIE instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_NO_CODE
sect2.para: The body of implementation or pattern needs to have at least one non-pseudo-copy instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_MULTI_ASSIGN
sect2.para: One argument or temporary is assigned multiple times in a single instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_IMAP_MULTI_INSTR
sect2.para: Only one instruction can appear in implementation.

sect2.title: TIE_IMM_OPERAND_DECODE
sect2.para: Decoding expression of immediate operands cannot be more than 32 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_IMM_OPERAND_NO_ENCODING
sect2.para: Missing encoding expression for immediate operand.

sect2.title: TIE_INCORRECT_NUMBER_OF_ARGUMENTS
sect2.para: The number of arguments expected by the construct was not matched.

sect2.title: TIE_INSTR_GROUP_ALL
sect2.para: If an instruction group (such as "xt_logical") is used in slot_opcodes, no instruction from that group can be added individually. Some groups such as xt_widebranch* can only be used as a group.

sect2.title: TIE_INSTR_GROUP_MULTIPLE
sect2.para: Only one instruction group of this class can be instantiated. This is applicable to wide branch instructions. Only one class of wide branch instructions can be added in FLIX. For example, adding xt_widebranch18 and xt_widebranch16 is illegal.

sect2.title: TIE_INST_NO_SLOT
sect2.para: Instruction does not appear in any slot. If the user TIE has no FLIX format, the tie instruction goes into the default 24 bit "Inst" slot. If the user TIE has FLIX, user should put the opcodes in slot(s) by adding a slot_opcode statement. If an opcode is not in any slot_opcode statement, then it is put into the Inst slot by default.

sect2.title: TIE_INST_MISSING_XFLIX_PROPERTY
sect2.para: Every core instruction should have either enFLIX property or nonFLIX property set. User instruction, however, may not have such properties.

sect2.title: TIE_INST_NAME_RESERVED
sect2.para: Instruction names starting with "ld.", "st.", or "mv." and finishing with a regfile or ctype name are reserved by TC. Instructions with those names must appear in at one of the "loadi", "storei", and "move" protos. The instructions must be the only instruction in those protos.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_CONN
sect2.para: Predefined interfaces such as "VAddr" or "MemDataIn/Out" should not be declared by the user. These are automatically declared. If the user does declare them, the interface specification must be the predefined specification.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_DIR
sect2.para: Predefined interfaces such as "VAddr" or "MemDataIn/Out" should not be declared by the user. These are automatically declared. If the user does declare them, the interface specification must be the predefined specification.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_ILLEGAL
sect2.para: Illegal interface description. Note that Predefined interfaces such as "VAddr" or "MemDataIn/Out" should not be declared by the user. These are automatically declared. If the user does declare them, the interface specification must be the predefined specification.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_ILLEGAL_DEFAULT
sect2.para: Internal use only. Please report to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_ILLEGAL_DEPENDENCY
sect2.para: Internal use only. Please report to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_INTERNAL
sect2.para: Using an unsupported interface.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_KILL_USE
sect2.para: The KILL signal for a TIE queue can only be assigned from an operation if the operation reads or writes the queue. If the operation argument list does not include the queue name, then it is illegal to add the Q_KILL interface of the queue to the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_LSSIZE_IGNORED
sect2.para: LSSize is an obsolete interface in the TIE language that was used to describe the size of the load/store memory data. This is no longer used. TIE compiler automatically derives the size. An old version of tie run with a new version of TIE compiler wil generate this warning. Please remove LSSize from your tie description.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_MAX_WIDTH
sect2.para: Maximum width of a tie port interface is 1024 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_NAME_CONFLICT
sect2.para: The tie port interface will generate either a top level port signal whose name will conflict with an another port. For example, the following tie will generate a top level input port called "TIE_IQ_Empty" from the queue "IQ", and another top level port called "TIE_IQ_Empty" from the import wire "IQ_Empty".

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_READ_STAGE
sect2.para: Illegal read/use stage for a tieport interface. This is an internal error and if reported indicates that the TIE compiler did not elaborate a tie port correctly to its internal format. It should be reported to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_STALL_ILLEGAL
sect2.para: Illegal stall specification for a tie port interface. This is an internal error and if reported indicates that the TIE compiler did not elaborate a tie port correctly to its internal format. It should be reported to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_STALL_USE
sect2.para: The tie port interface is internally used for generating a stall and should not be directly used in a operation. For example, the Empty/Full interface of a queue, if read directly into an operation will generate this warning, because it is used to generate a stall automatically. The signal NOTRDY should be used to check the status of the queue.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_TYPE
sect2.para: Illegal type in interface description. Note that Predefined interfaces such as "VAddr" or "MemDataIn/Out" should not be declared by the user. These are automatically declared. If the user does declare them, the interface specification must be the predefined specification.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_WIDTH
sect2.para: Illegal width in interface description. Note that Predefined interfaces such as "VAddr" or "MemDataIn/Out" should not be declared by the user. These are automatically declared. If the user does declare them, the interface specification must be the predefined specification.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERFACE_WRITE_STAGE
sect2.para: Illegal write/def stage for a tieport interface. This is an internal error and if reported indicates that the TIE compiler did not elaborate a tie port correctly to its internal format. It should be reported to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_INTERNAL
sect2.para: Internal error in TIE compiler due to a bug. When this happens, the file tc_errlog.txt in the tdk directory may have more information.

sect2.title: TIE_KEYWORD
sect2.para: A TIE/C/Verilog language keyword cannot be used as the name of a tie variable.

sect2.title: TIE_LENGTH_ALREADY_DEFINED
sect2.para: A lwngth with the same name as already been defined.

sect2.title: TIE_LENGTH_OVERLAP
sect2.para: The decoding logic of two lengths overlap. For example, in the following code (assuming a 64 bit instruction word in a little Endian configuration), the decoding logic for "len64" and "len32" are overlapping.
length len64 64 { InstBuf[3:0] == 15 } length len32 32 { InstBuf[3:0] == 15 }

sect2.title: TIE_LENGTH_WRONG_DECODER
sect2.para: Legal decoding expressions for decoding length are restricted to the form
InstBuf[from:to] == <constant> [ && InstBuf[from:to] == <constant> ]

This is to ensure that the decoding logic can meet the timing constraints for decoding the instruction. Decoding logic should not have arbitrary amount of logic. Also, the length decoding can only use bits InstBuf[3:0] or InstBuf[63:60] in LittleEndian and BigEndian configurations respectively.

sect2.title: TIE_LENGTH_WRONG_SIZE
sect2.para: Incorrect length size. Legal lengths are 32 or 64 as the configuration permits. For example, a configuration with a instruction word length of 32 cannot have a length declaration of size 64.

sect2.title: TIE_LENGTH_SLOT_DISJOINT
sect2.para: The bits used by the decoding logic of a length are also being used by a slot in the format. For example, in the following code, InstBuf[3:0] is being used for decoding the format x64. The slot "slot1" as defined here occupies bits InstBuf[60:0]. Therefore the bits InstBuf[3:0] has a conflict.

sect2.title: TIE_LICENSE
sect2.para: Could not get a license for a specific feature. The TIE compiler needs a license to run, and specific licenses for H/W generation and are LX are also needed. TIE compiler uses FLEXLM license mechanism. Please check license availability using "lmstat" command.

sect2.title: TIE_LIST_OVERLAP
sect2.para: Some TIE variables can appear in only one list. The same opcode cannot appear in the instruction list of more than one iclass, schedule, or semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_LOADSTORE_NO_PROTO
sect2.para: If a load or store instruction is explicitly written by the user, then a proto should also be written for the instruction with the appropriate argument for data and address. Otherwise, the TIE compiler will generate a proto for the load and store which may be incorrect.
If the TIE compiler generates the load or store instruction, then the proto will also be generated correctly.
This warning is not seen by default, unless the TIE compiler is run with the flag -warnall.

sect2.title: TIE_LOOKUP_WRITE_STAGE
sect2.para: A lookup request can be written in the stages E to W only.

sect2.title: TIE_LOOKUP_LATENCY
sect2.para: The latency of the lookup operation is (read stage - write stage) of the lookup. Since the latency must be >= 1, therefore the read stage of the lookup must be at least one cycle after the write stage.

sect2.title: TIE_LOOKUP_RDY
sect2.para: A "Rdy" input in a lookup is used to indicate if the external device is accepting the lookup request sent by Xtensa processor. If "Rdy" is low, the processor stalls. To make this stall be interruptible by external interrupts or internal exceptions, the stall must be effective before the instruction commit stage (W). Therefore, Rdy is allowed only

item.itemtext: in stage E in a 5-stage configuration
in stage L in a 7-stage configuration.

sect2.title: TIE_LOOKUP_USAGE
sect2.para: Lookup consists of an output and an input port that must be used atomically within an instruction. This means that an operation or instruction must use both interface or port. It is illegal to use the interfaces individually.

sect2.title: TIE_LOOKUP_INVALID_WIDTH
sect2.para: Lookup input and output width must be a positive number.

sect2.title: TIE_LS_UNIT_ALLOCATION_ERROR
sect2.para: Xtensa processor supports upto 2 load/store units for FLIX configurations. With two load/store units, a FLIX format can have load/store instructions in two slots. However, with one load/store unit, load/store instructions can appear in one slot only, and furthermore that slot has to be the slot index 0 or the first slot in a format.

sect2.title: TIE_LS_UNIT_MULTIPLE_SLOT
sect2.para: A load/store unit cannot be used in multiple slots. This error can only be generated when the TIE compiler has assigned load/store units incorrectly. Hence this is an internal error and should be reported to Tensilica.

sect2.title: TIE_LS_UNIT_SLOTS
sect2.para: Number of load/store units cannot accomodate load/store operations in these slots. Xtensa processor supports upto 2 load/store units for FLIX configurations. With two load/store units, a FLIX format can have load/store instructions in two slots. However, with one load/store unit, load/store instructions can appear in one slot only, and furthermore that slot has to be the slot index 0 or the first slot in a format.

sect2.title: TIE_MAC
sect2.para: MR register file in MAC16 package is special. It cannot be used by user. This error is generated if the user tries to use the MR register file.

sect2.title: TIE_MACRO
sect2.para: Error in using a TIE module. For a list of TIE modules and their usage, see the TIE language Reference Manual. Some of the specific errors are listed below:

item.itemtext: TIEmul : must have three arguments, last argument that specifies signed multiply must be 1 bit.
TIEmulpp, TIEmac : the arguments specifying negate and sign must be 1 bit.
TIEcsa : must have 4 arguments.
TIEadd : must have 3 arguments, the argument specifying carry in must be 1 bit.
TIEcmp : the first two arguments must be the same width.
TIEmux : number of arguments must be power of 2.

sect2.title: TIE_MACRO_SIGNAL_WIDTH
sect2.para: Incorrect width of argument to a tie module. Restrictions are:

item.itemtext: Select signal of TIEmux must be log2 of the number of data arguments
Each select signal of TIEsel must be width 1.

sect2.para: Note that all immediate operands created using immediate_range, tables, and the operand construct are defined to be 32 bits wide. If an immediate operand is being used in the TIE module, please ensure that appropriate bits of the operand are selected.

sect2.title: TIE_MULPP_ASSIGNMENT
sect2.para: This warning is not seen by default. Please run TIE compiler with -warnall flag.

sect2.title: TIE_MULPP_PARTIAL_PRODUCT_SUM
sect2.para: This warning is not seen by default. Please run TIE compiler with -warnall flag.

sect2.title: TIE_MULPP_PARTIAL_PRODUCT_USE
sect2.para: This warning is not seen by default. Please run TIE compiler with -warnall flag.

sect2.title: TIE_MULTIPLE_ASSIGNMENT
sect2.para: There are more than one assignments to a wire or output.

sect2.title: TIE_MULT_COPROC
sect2.para: An instruction can only access states or register files that belong to a single coprocessor. This restriction exists to ensure that an instruction can generate a single coprocessor exception.

sect2.title: TIE_NAME_DUP
sect2.para: Duplicate name found in the same scope. Note that although TIE language is case sensitive, duplicate name check in a scope is performed in a case-insensitive way to avoid naming conflicts in tools that read the output of TIE compiler generated RTL. For example, the following code will generate an error.
state TEST_DUP 32 state Test_Dup 40

sect2.title: TIE_NO_TCTOOLS
sect2.para: The installation directory for TIE compiler could not be found.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_DECL
sect2.para: The variable used in the statements has not been declared as an input or output to this block. For example, to use a variable inside an operation, the variable must be declared in the argument list of the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_DEFINED
sect2.para: Some variables must be defined before they are used. For example, a state or register file must be defined before it can be used in an operation.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_DEFINED_CASE
sect2.para: Some variables must be defined before they are used. This warning is issued when a variable only differs by case from another one.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_FOUND
sect2.para: A variable used has not been defined.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_SUPPORTED
sect2.para: The feature is not supported in this version of TIE language.

sect2.title: TIE_NOT_CONFIGURED
sect2.para: Certain Xtensa configuration options are required to use some features of TIE language

sect2.title: TIE_NO_ASSIGNMENT
sect2.para: All outputs of an operation must be assigned to in the body of the operation or semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_NO_READ
sect2.para: A variable name can appear on the right hand side of an assignment only if it is declared as an input in the current scope. Outputs of an operation or function can only appear in the left hand side of an assignment.

sect2.title: TIE_NO_USE
sect2.para: The input to an operation or a function has not been used in the body of the operation or function.

sect2.title: TIE_NO_VALID_INSTR
sect2.para: There must be a valid instruction with this name. For example, writing a schedule for an instruction for which there is no implementation (reference, operation, or semantic) is illegal. Note that an opcode is not an instruction until it has an implementation in any of these forms.

sect2.title: TIE_NO_WRITE
sect2.para: A variable name can appear on the left hand side of an assignment only if it is declared as an output in the current scope. Inputs of an operation or function can only appear in the right hand side of an assignment.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_DENSITY
sect2.para: A user TIE instruction can be the default instruction size of 24 bits, or part of a FLIX instruction. It cannot be defined as a density (16 bit) instruction. If the encoding of an instruction sets the bits in the instruction word that decodes it as a 16bit instruction, an error is generated.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_ENCODING
sect2.para: Incorrect encoding for an opcode. For example, the following code will generate an error

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_FIELD_SIZE_ONLY
sect2.para: Opcode encoding is defined as <field>=<value>, where the field must be defined precisely in every slot that the opcode belongs to. Using a field that is not mapped to specific bits of a slot generates an error. Note that the TIE compiler automatically generates encodings for operations. For example, the following opcode encoding is illegal because the field "fldx" is not fully specified in the slot "slot1".
field fldx slot1[*] opcode check fldx=4'd15

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_FIELD_UNDEFINED
sect2.para: Opcode encoding is defined as <field>=<value>, where the field must be defined in every slot that the opcode belongs to. Using a field that is not defined in encoding generates an error. Note that the TIE compiler automatically generates encodings for operations.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_MULTI_DEF
sect2.para: An opcode can have only one encoding in a slot. It can have multiple encodings that apply to different slots. For example, in the following code, since the fields "x" and "y" are both defined both in slot1, the opcode "check" has multiple definitions in slot1.
field x slot1[21:18] field y slot1[15:12] opcode multi x=4'd15 opcode multi y=4'd15

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_NON_INST_SLOT_ONLY
sect2.para: An instruction can be added to a slot with the "slot_opcodes" statement only if it is a valid instruction, i.e. it has a valid implementation.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_NO_ICLASS
sect2.para: An opcode must have an iclass to be implemented in a reference or semantic. An iclass defines the input and output operands of the instruction. Note that an instruction written as an operation combines the iclass and reference.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_NO_IMPL
sect2.para: An instruction that is defined with an opcode and a iclass must have an implementation in the form of a reference or a semantic, or both. Note that an instruction written as an operation combines the iclass and reference.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_NO_SLOT
sect2.para: All instructions must belong to at least one slot. By default, all user TIE instructions appear in the 24 bit "Inst" slot. If the user has a FLIX format, an instruction must be added to a FLIX format with a slot_opcodes statement.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_OPERAND_OVERLAP
sect2.para: The field used for encoding an instruction is the same as that used for encoding an operand of an instruction. In the following example, the "r" field is used for encoding the opcode as well the operand arr.
opcode MYOP r=4'b0000 CUST0 iclass MYOP { MYOP } { out arr , in ars }
Error: (TIE_OPCODE_OPERAND_OVERLAP), For instruction MYOP in slot Inst, opcode MYOP overlaps with field r used in operand arr

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_OVERLAP
sect2.para: The encodings of all opcodes in a slot must be disjoint. For example, in the following code, the encoding of MYOP1 and MYOP2 overlap.
field op2b op2[1:0] opcode MYOP1 op2=4'b1111 CUST0 opcode MYOP2 op2b=2'b11 CUST0

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_PARENT_AMBIGUOUS
sect2.para: Encoding of an opcode in a slot is not fully specified.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_PARENT_UNDEFINED
sect2.para: Parent opcode in an opcode encoding is not defined.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_REQ_SLOT
sect2.para: An opcode that is requested in a slot with a slot_opcodes statement is not be defined in that slot. For an opcode to be defined in a slot, all fields needed to encode the opcode and its operands must be defined in that slot.

sect2.title: TIE_OPCODE_UNIQUE_SLOT
sect2.para: A opcode can be defined in a slot by using a simple definition, or full encoding as shown below
opcode MYOP slot1 // simple definition, encoding not specified
OR
field fldx slot1[21:18] opcode MYOP fldx=4'd15 // encoding specified
However mixing the two formats is illegal as shown below.
opcode MYOP slot1 fldy=2'b11 //illegal

sect2.title: TIE_OPERAND_AR_ILL
sect2.para: User cannot define operands on AR register file. The only allowed operands on AR regfile are: ars, art, arr.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERAND_CORE_OPERAND
sect2.para: Xtensa core operands such as "ars" cannot be redefined by user TIE.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERAND_OPERAND_OVERLAP
sect2.para: An instruction has two operands whose encoding fields overlap.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERAND_RHS
sect2.para: Operand appears on the left hand side of assignment.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERAND_MAP_ARG_ERR
sect2.para: The argument of operand_map construct contains error. The error is that the operand, operation, or operation argument is missing in the TIE file.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_AMBIGUOUS_NAME
sect2.para: Conflicting variable name in an operation. For example, in the following code, the operation TESTDUP has an input VAddr, which could be the interface or the state.
state VAddr 32 operation TESTDUP { out AR a } { in VAddr }
Error: (TIE_OPERATION_AMBIGUOUS_NAME), "VAddr" is ambiguous in operation's body, could be state or interface

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_ARG_AMBIGUOUS
sect2.para: Conflicting argument name in an operation. An argument cannot have the same name as the operation because the name of the operation is an implicit input to the operation with a constant value of 1.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_ARG_DIR
sect2.para: The direction of the operation argument is wrong. Immediate operands, immediate ranges, tables must be input operands.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_AMBIGUOUS_TYPE
sect2.para: Conflicting argument type in an operation. Valid argument types are register files, operands, tables. For example, in the following code,
Error: (TIE_OPERATION_AMBIGUOUS_TYPE), Argument "a" has ambiguous type XR, could be regfile or table

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_ARG_WIRE_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Wire names in the operation body cannot be the same as the operation argument.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_CASE_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Operation name and opcode names must match exactly if both opcode and operation is provided. If an operation name matches an opcode name but varies only in case, this is an error.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_CONFLICT
sect2.para: An instruction can be defined as an operation, or as an opcode/iclass/reference, but not both.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_CORE_STATE
sect2.para: User defined operations cannot read Xtensa core states. The only exception is the state SAR, which holds the shift amount for some shift operations.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_DUPLICATE_ARG
sect2.para: Same operation argument name declared twice. Operation argument names must be unique in a case insensitive manner.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_DUP_OPERAND
sect2.para: An operation argument type can be a register file name, or an operand name. If the argument is written as a register file, then an operand will be generated for it. If it is written as an operand, then it will be used directly. In this latter case, each operand used as an argument must be unique.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_IMPLICIT_OPERAND
sect2.para: There are some implicit operands in the Xtensa core which read a register file but the index is fixed or not encoded in the instruction. These operands cannot be used in user TIE operations.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_INTERFACE_DIR
sect2.para: Interface declared in the operation state-interface list does not match the direction in the interface definition. For example, in the following code, the interface MemDataIn32 is declared as an output of the operation MYOP, which is incorrect since MemDataIn32 is an input interface.
operation MYOP { out AR d, in AR p } { out VAddr, out MemDataIn32 }
Error: (TIE_OPERATION_INTERFACE_DIR), Operation MYOP, interface MemDataIn32 declared as out but it should be in

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_INVALID_KILL
sect2.para: Output operands of operations can have be updated conditionally. An implicit output named <output_name>_kill can be assigned in the operation body. If this output is true, the update of the register operand is killed. To assign a kill signal in an operation body, there should be a valid output declared in the operation argument.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_INVALID_STATE_KILL
sect2.para: Output states of operations can have be updated conditionally. An implicit output named <state_name>_kill can be assigned in the operation body. If this output is true, the update of the state is killed. To assign a kill signal in an operation body, the state should be declared as an output of the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_INVALID_INTERFACE_KILL
sect2.para: An operation reading or writing a TIE queue can use the "_KILL" interfaces to conditionally read or write the queue. In this case, the queue itself must be an input or output of the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_NO_DEP
sect2.para: The input to the operation is not being used to generate any of the outputs. This is determined by analyzing the body of the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_NO_SEMANTIC
sect2.para: An operation usually contains the arguments and a body that represents the implementation of the instruction. In the case where the operation is also implemented in a semantic, the operation body can be left blank. However, the operation must have at least one implementation in either form.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_OPERAND_REGFILE_NUM
sect2.para: The number of arguments in the operation that reads a register file exceeds the number of entries in the register file. For example, an operation cannot read 5 inputs from a register file with 4 entries.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_POINTER_ARG
sect2.para: An operation argument can be declared as a pointer. This is usually done when writing load/store operations. The pointer argument is declared as a pointer to a register file or operand type, which means that the address to the data in memory for that register file is stored in the pointer. Pointers are always 32 bits and kept in the AR register file. Pointer arguments are allowed for register arguments only. For example, in the following code, the operation MYOP declares a pointer to an immediate range, which is illegal.
operation MYOP { out AR a, in IMMRANGE *b} {out VAddr, in MemDataIn32}
Error: (TIE_OPERATION_POINTER_ARG), Operation argument b cannot be a pointer. Pointers allowed only for regfile arguments.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_REF_OPERAND
sect2.para: When an operation argument type is an operand, the argument name should still be used in the operation body instead of the operand name. For example, in the following code, the valid variable names in the body of MYOP are the arguments "a" and "b", and not the operand names "ars" and "arr".
operation MYOP { out arr a, in ars b } {}

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_REQUIRES_STATE
sect2.para: An operation can be required to use a certain state.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_SAME_ARG_TYPE
sect2.para: In an operation, argument types and names must be unique, i.e. an argument name cannot be the same as the type name of another argument. For example, in the following code, the operation MYOP has an argument type IMMOP and an argument name IMMOP.
operation MYOP { out AR IMMOP, in IMMOP b } {}

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_UNKNOWN_ARG
sect2.para: Argument type in operation declaration is unknown, i.e. it is not a register file, operand, immediate range or table.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_VERIFY_INVALID
sect2.para: Argument in operation's state interface list is unknown, i.e. it is not a state or interface.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_VERIFY_MISSING
sect2.para: A state or interface declared as an input or output in the declaration is not being read or assigned to in the operation body.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATION_VERIFY_UNEXPECTED
sect2.para: A state or interface that is being assigned to or read from in the operation body has not been declared as an output or input in the declaration.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATOR_PROTO_ARG
sect2.para: The argument of the proto used in operator construct is wrong. It is possibly because: 1. argument of direction inout is used. 2. number of arguments does not match specification. 3. immediate values are used in argument.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATOR_PROTO_CASE
sect2.para: The proto used in operator construct and the defined proto are different in case.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATOR_UNDEFINED_PROTO
sect2.para: The proto used in operator construct is not defined.

sect2.title: TIE_OPERATOR_UNKNOWN
sect2.para: The operator type is not in the supported list.

sect2.title: TIE_OPER_AND_SEM
sect2.para: An instruction can have two implementations in TIE language. One is the operation or reference, and the other is the semantic. A semantic is usually written to share the implementation of more than one instruction in the same module. If both implementations exist, the TIE compiler generates netlists and scripts to formally verify that the two are equivalent. The user is encouraged to a tool like Verplex or Formality to formally check the two implementations.
This message is not shown by default. It can be seen when running TIE compiler with -msgall flag.

sect2.title: TIE_PREDEFINED
sect2.para: User TIE cannot define an instruction that is predefined in the Xtensa core.

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_ARGUMENT_MISMATCH
sect2.para: This error occurs when the conversions ( i.e. %d, %x, etc. ) and the formatting arguments given to a TIEprint module do not correlate. Make sure you have the same number of conversions in your formatting string as arguments in the argument list.
Examples:

item.itemtext: This TIEprint has two conversions specified but only one argument: TIEprint( "Two conversions, %d, %08x, one argument\n", address );
This TIEprint has one conversion, but two arguments: TIEprint( "One conversion, %d, two arguments\n", address, align );

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_ARGUMENT_TOO_WIDE
sect2.para: Arguments to TIEprint modules must be <= 32 bits. If an expression is used as an argument in a TIEprint module the result of this expression must be <= 32 bits. If you want to print a variable or expression that is longer than 32 bits use bit selects to split the argument into pieces smaller than 32 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_ILLEGAL_FORMATTING
sect2.para: Conversions in a TIEprint module formatting string must be in an allowed format. Currently allowed conversions are;

item.itemtext: %d: signed decimal
%x: unsigned hexadecimal
%u: unsigned decimal
%[0-9][0-9]*[d,u,x]: [0-9]* characters printed in representation given by [d,u,x]. If [0-9] is present at the beginning of the conversion padded with leading characters based on the number given.

sect2.para: Please review all conversions and make sure that they match the syntax given above.

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_ILLEGAL_VARIABLE
sect2.para: An illegal variable or expression is used in a TIEprint module. The offending expression will be printed along with the error message. Please review the expression and make sure all variables are legal in the current scope.

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_TOO_MANY_ARGUMENTS
sect2.para: You are only allowed 32 arguments to a single TIEprint module. Please use more than one TIEprint module if you wish to print more than 32 arguments.

sect2.title: TIE_PRINT_QUALIFIER_TOO_WIDE
sect2.para: The qualifier in a TIEprint module must be <= 32 bits wide.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_ARG_COUNT_MISMATCH
sect2.para: The number of in, out and inout arguments that the two protos should be the same.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_ARG_DUP
sect2.para: The argument appears more than once in the argument list.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_EXPORT_SAME
sect2.para: The export property of some states should be identical.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_ILLEGAL_ARG
sect2.para: The property has an illegal argument, or the argument is not recognized by TIE compiler.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_MISSING
sect2.para: The name, attribute, or the arguments is missing in the property.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_NONFLIX_INSTRUCTION
sect2.para: Some Xtensa core instructions are not allowed in a FLIX format.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_WRONG_ARGS
sect2.para: The arguments of the property is wrong. It may be because: 1. The number of arguments is not expected. 2. For shared_semantic property, same slot index appear in multiple sharing groups.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_UNKNOWN
sect2.para: The property is not recognized by TIE compiler.

sect2.title: TIE_PROPERTY_UNKNOWN_ATTR
sect2.para: The property has an unknown attribute.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ADDRESS_POINTER
sect2.para: A load or store prototype is written to indicate to the compiler how to get data from the register file to memory and vice versa. The proto must conform to strict rules for the compiler to use it. The second argument of the proto must be a pointer to the data type in the register file for which the proto is being written. The following are examples of correct protos
regfile XR 64 16 xr ctype data64 64 64 XR
proto data64_loadi { out data64 d, in data64 *p, in immediate o } {} { //load instruction } proto data64_storei { in data64 d, in data64 *p, in immediate o } {} { //store instruction }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ADDRESS_UPDATE
sect2.para: A load or store prototype is written to indicate to the compiler how to get data from the register file to memory and vice versa. The proto must conform to strict rules for the compiler to use it. There are two categories of load/store protos with immediate offset. The loadi/storei protos don't update the address register with the address computed, and the loadiu/storeiu protos update the address register with the computed address. The instructions used in the protos must be appropriate. Following are examples of some illegal protos
regfile XR 64 16 xr ctype data64 64 64 XR

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_DIR
sect2.para: A prototype has one or more instructions which are called with the arguments to the proto. The direction of the proto arguments should match the direction of the operands of the instruction in the proto body. For example, in the following code, the move prototype has an input argument "d" and an output argument "v", but in the proto body the move instruction MOV.S has been called with the argument "d" and "v" as the output and input argument respectively.
regfile XR 64 16 xr ctype data64 64 64 XR
operation MOV.S { out XR a, in XR b } { assign a = b; }
proto data64_move { out data64 d, in data64 v } {} { MOV.S v, d; }
Note that protos are automatically generated by TIE compiler for all operations.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_KILL_ARG_DIR
sect2.para: If a proto uses an instruction whose output has a conditional kill, the corresponding proto argument must be an "inout" instead of "out". This is because the compiler needs to recognize the read-modify-write nature of the operation. For example, in the following code, the proto for the conditional move instruction MOV.T must have the output argument "d" declared as inout.
regfile XR 64 16 xr ctype data64 64 64 XR
operation MOV.T { out XR a, in XR b } { assign a = b; assign a_kill = b[0]; }
proto data64_move { inout data64 d, in data64 v } {} { MOV.T d, v; }
Note that when TIE compiler automatically generates protos for all operations with the correct argument direction taking into consideration the kill.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_DUP
sect2.para: Duplicate argument in proto.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_FIELD_DEFINED
sect2.para: Input argument field of the proto was used as an output argument in an instruction in the body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_FIELD_NO_USE
sect2.para: Input argument field of the proto has not been used in the body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_OUT_FIELD_USE
sect2.para: Output argument field of the proto is used as an input. There are a few cases where it is useful to use ANY register in such a way that it generates a constant. If this is desired, as in using \"XOR b, a, a\" to generate 0 in b, use a temporary.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_OUT_FIELD_NO_DEF
sect2.para: Output argument field of the proto has not been used in the body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_OUT_FIELD_UNDECLARED
sect2.para: Input argument field of the proto has not been used in the body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_NO_USE
sect2.para: Input argument or temporary argument of proto has not been used in the body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_OUT
sect2.para: Output argument of proto has issues. It may not be used in the proto body, or assigned value multiple times in the proto body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_ORDER
sect2.para: A load and store prototype is written to indicate to the compiler how to get data from the register file to memory and vice versa. A move prototype tells the compiler how to copy data between two registers. Protos can also be written to convert between two data types. These protos must conform to strict rules for the compiler to use it. For a list of all the protos, please refer to TIE language Ref Manual.

item.itemtext: *For a load proto, the first argument must be an output of the ctype.
*For a store proto, the first argument must be an input of the cytpe.
*For a move proto, the first argument must be an output of ctype.
*For load/store proto, the second argument must be an input of type pointer to the ctype. This specifies the address.
*For a move proto, the first argument must be an input of the cytpe.
*If a third argument exists for a load/store proto, it must be an immediate for the loadi/storei proto, or a ctype mapped to AR (uint32, int32) for the indexed proto loadx/storex.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_POINTER
sect2.para: Some ctypes when used in protos can only be pointers. These are 64 bit data types "uint64" and "int64", as well as "void".

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_STRUCT
sect2.para: Struct ctypes are not allowed in instruction protos.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ARG_TYPE
sect2.para: Proto arguments that are register operands must be valid ctypes defined for that register file. Also, note that "char" cannot be used as a proto argument, "uint8" or "int8" should be used, due to the ambiguity of the behavior of "char" being signed or unsigned.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_CASE_FIELD
sect2.para: In a proto, a code argument must have only valid fields specified for it. This error is issued when a field of the same name exists, but differs in case from the field specified.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_DECL
sect2.para: Argument used in proto body has not been declared in the proto declaration.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_NONIMM_OFFSET
sect2.para: Immediate constant offsets can be added to instruction arguments in proto body only for immediate operands. For example, in the following code, the argument "c + 1" for the immediate operand is legal, but the argument "b + 2" for the register operand is illegal.
operation my.add { in AR a, in AR b, in simm8 off } {} { assign a = b + offset; }
proto my_add_3 { out uint32 a, in uint32 b, in immediate c } { } { my.add a, b + 2, c + 1; }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_NO_FIELD
sect2.para: In a proto, a code argument with ctypes that represents a single register may not have a field specified for it.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_REQUIRED_FIELD
sect2.para: In a proto, a code argument with ctypes that represents multiple registers that are not a register view must have a field specifier to identify which register to use.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_INVALID_FIELD
sect2.para: In a proto, a code argument must have only valid fields specified for it.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_NUM
sect2.para: The number of arguments to an instruction in a proto body must match the number of arguments in the instruction. For example, in the following code, the proto my_add_3 calls the instruction "my.add" with only 2 arguments instead of 3.
operation my.add { in AR a, in AR b, in simm8 off } {} { assign a = b + offset; }
proto my_add_3 { out uint32 a, in uint32 b } { } { my.add a, b; }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_REGFILE
sect2.para: When a proto input or output argument of a certain ctype is passed to an instruction in its body, the underlying register file of the ctype must be the register file of the instruction input/output. For example, in the following code, the proto "my_add_3" calls the instruction "my.add" with the output argument a, which in the proto is mapped to the AR register file, but in the instruction is mapped to the XR register file.
regfile XR 64 16 xr ctype data64 64 64 XR
operation my.add { in XR a, in XR b, in simm8 off } {} { assign a = b + offset; }
proto my_add_3 { out uint32 a, in data64 b, in immediate o } { } { my.add a, b, o; }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_TEMP_OFFSET
sect2.para: A proto can have temporary variables to hold intermediate results when the body contains more than one instruction. However, when using the temporary variables in the body, no offset can be added. For example, in the following code, the temporary variable "x" cannot be used as "x+2".

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_TYPE
sect2.para: The argument type of the proto argument used as an input or output operand of an instruction in the body must match the operand type in the instruction. For example, in the following code, the proto "my_add_3" calls the instruction "my.add" with the third argument as "b" which is a register operand and does not match the immediate operand of instruction "my.add".
operation my.add { in AR a, in AR b, in simm8 off } {} { assign a = b + offset; }
proto my_add_3 { out uint32 a, in uint32 b } { } { my.add a, b, b; }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODEARG_BASE_ADDRESS
sect2.para: In a load/store proto, the second argument to the proto is the address pointer. This is the argument that should be used as the base address input to the load/store instruction in the proto body. For example, in the following code, the address argument p is not being used as the base address input p to the load instruction L32I.
proto load_add64 { out data64 d, in data64 *p, in data64 p1 } {} { load_add d, p1, p; }

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CODE_ADDRESS
sect2.para: The load/store instructions used in load/store protos must conform to strict addressing rules. The address must be generated from any of the following:

item.itemtext: VAddr = AR register operand
VAddr = AR register operand + immediate offset for loadi/storei
VAddr = AR register operand + AR register operand for loadx/storex

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CORE_PROTO
sect2.para: A user defined proto cannot have the same name as an Xtensa core proto.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_CTYPE_CONFLICT
