sect2.para: A proto name is the same as a ctype name, which is not legal.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ILLEGAL_COPROC
sect2.para: Load and store protos can only generate one coprocessor exception.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_INSTR_CODEARG_OFFSET
sect2.para: All instructions in user TIE have a corresponding proto. This is automatically generated by the TIE compiler. If the user writes an instruction proto, the argument in the proto body must come directly from the proto arguments. No offsets are allowed.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_INSTR_CODEARG_SEQUENCE
sect2.para: All instructions in user TIE have a corresponding proto. This is automatically generated by the TIE compiler. If the user writes an instruction proto, the arguments in the proto body must have the same sequence as the arguments in proto arguments.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_INSTR_NUM_ARGUMENTS
sect2.para: All instructions in user TIE have a corresponding proto. This is automatically generated by the TIE compiler. If the user writes an instruction proto, the number of arguments of the proto must be the same as the number of arguments in the proto body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_INVALID_OPCODE
sect2.para: The opcode name used inside the proto body is not a valid instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_LOADSTORE_DATA
sect2.para: The load/store instructions used in load/store protos must conform to strict rules. The memory data in a load instruction must be directly assigned to the output register. Similarly, the memory data in a store instruction should be directly assigned from the input register.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_MEMSIZE
sect2.para: The load/store instructions used in load/store protos must conform to strict rules. The size of the memory data (MemDataIn/MemDataOut) must be at least the size of the ctype. For example, a single load instruction that uses MemDataIn32 cannot be used in the loadi proto for a ctype that is 40 bits wide. Note that, two such loads in the loadi proto would be legal.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_MISSING
sect2.para: All instructions must have a corresponding proto, either written by user or generated automatically by TIE compiler. In some cases, the user has to explicitly write instruction protos. For example, if a register file used by the instruction has multiple ctypes, none of which could be identified as a default ctype for the register file, then TIE compiler will not generate the instruction proto.

Similarly, all ctypes must have at least loadi/storei/move prototypes. These can be generated automatically by the TIE compiler in most cases. However, in some cases TIE compiler cannot do it due to restrictions. For example, if a ctype of size 64 bits exists in a Xtensa configuration with memory size of 32 bits, TIE compiler will not automatically generate a load/store proto with two load/store instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_NO_CODE
sect2.para: Blank proto body.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_NO_TEMP
sect2.para: No temporary variables are allowed for certain protos.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_NUM_ARGS
sect2.para: Some protos can only have a strict number of arguments. For example, loadi/storei protos cannot have more than 3 arguments.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_NUM_TEMP
sect2.para: Some protos can only have a strict number of temporary variables.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_OLD_RURWUR_REF
sect2.para: A proto is using an old style RUR/WUR instruction which is being automatically converted to the new style.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_ONE_OPCODE
sect2.para: Instruction proto (one proto per instruction) which has the same name as the instruction must use only one opcode.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_OPERATION_NAME_CASE
sect2.para: Proto names and operation names cannot be different only in case, or different using '.' or '_' letters. They can be exactly the same or totally different. If proto names and operation names are exactly the same, the proto is an instruction proto containing only the operation.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_TEMP_TYPE
sect2.para: Proto temporaries must be have valid ctypes.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_TEMP_TYPE_CASE
sect2.para: Proto temporaries must be have valid ctypes. This error is issued when a ctype of the same name exists, but differs in case from the ctype specified.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_TEMP_WRONG_CTYPE
sect2.para: For load/store protos, the type of the only temporary variable cannot share the same register file as the ctype intended to load or store.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_UNUSED
sect2.para: The proto is unused by XCC. For rtom and rtor converstion protos, XCC does not use the conversion proto if the source ctype is one of the following: uint8, int8, uint16, int16.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_WRONG_CONVERT
sect2.para: Conversion protos are written to convert a datatype to another. They are of the following form:

item.itemtext: <ctype_from>_rtor_<ctype_to>, for both datatypes are in registers.
<ctype_from>_mtor_<ctype_to>, for converting ctype_from in memory to ctype_to in register.
<ctype_from>_rtom_<ctype_to>, for converting ctype_from in register to ctype_to in memory.

sect2.para: Both ctypes must be valid in the above protos.

sect2.title: TIE_PROTO_WRONG_MOVE
sect2.para: Move prototype must use instruction that does a strict register to register move without any computation or conditional move. This analysis of move instruction used in the proto can be done by analyzing a shared semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_CORE_REGFILE
sect2.para: An Xtensa core register file (such as AR, BR, MR) cannot be redefined in user TIE. Also, user tie cannot redefine the number of callee saved entries in the core register files.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_ILLEGAL_DEPTH
sect2.para: Number of entries in a register file must be power of 2 to generate efficient addressing bits for indexing.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_ILLEGAL_SNAME
sect2.para: A register file "short name" is used in all software tools. This name must be upto 6 characters long and cannot contain "." in it. This is to ensure correctness of all s/w tools including debugger.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_MAX_DEPTH
sect2.para: User defined register files can have a maximum of 1024 entries.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_DEPTH
sect2.para: User defined register files can have up to a maximum of 1024 entries. However, register files with more than 128 entries require an enhanced version of the XCC compiler to compile C/C++ programs targeted for such a TIE design. Using the default version of the XCC compiler that you have downloaded as part of the software tools will result in an error. If you plan to use register files with more than 128 entries, please contact your Tensilica support engineer to request the enhanced version of the XCC compiler.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_MAX_NUMBER
sect2.para: The XCC compiler has a restriction on number of register files. A total of 24 register files can exist in the core (Xtensa + user TIE).

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_MULTI_DEFAULT_CTYPE
sect2.para: Register file has multiple default ctypes defined. Only one ctype can be specified as default.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NO_CTYPE
sect2.para: All register files must have at least one datatype (ctype) associated with it to be recognized by the compiler. If a register file is declared in user tie and no ctype is added, the TIE compiler creates a default one with the same name as the register file, if it can. There is currently no way to have a register file that is not recognized by the compiler.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NO_LOADSTORE
sect2.para: All register files must have load and store instructions to read and write the contents to memory. If a register file is added in user tie and no load/store instructions are created, the TIE compiler will automatically generate the load store instructions if it can.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NO_READ_PORT
sect2.para: All register files must have at least one read port, i.e. at least one use/read of the register file.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NO_WRITE_PORT
sect2.para: All register files must have at least one write port, i.e. at least one def/write to the register file.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_PROTO_GENERATION
sect2.para: All register files must have a datatype associated with it along with loadi/storei protos to read/write it from memory. TIE compiler will automatically generate the ctype and protos, and the load/store instructions. The load/store instructions generated automatically are called "ld.REGFILE" and "st.REGFILE". If user manually writes instructions/operations that are named the same as these, then TIE compiler expects them to be the correct load/store instructions that can be used by the proto.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_SIZE_GT_PIF
sect2.para: All register files must have a datatype associated with it along with loadi/storei protos to read/write it from memory. TIE compiler will automatically generate the ctype and protos, and the load/store instructions. The case where it cannot automatically generate the load/store instructions is when the memory width of the processor is less than the width of the register file. In this case, the TIE compiler will not automatically generate multiple load/stores.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_SNAME_DEFINED
sect2.para: The shortname for the register file is already defined for another register file. Shortnames, used by s/w tools, must be unique.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_SNAME_RESERVED
sect2.para: Shortnames used by Xtensa core register files are reserved and cannot be used by user TIE. These are "sp fp i l L r a b m".

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NUMERIC_SNAME
sect2.para: A shortname cannot end with a number. This is because register index is added to the shortname for describing an entry in the register file and a short name such as "r1" can generate "r10" for index 0, which cannot be distinguished from a short name "r" index 10.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_NUM_CALLEE_SAVED
sect2.para: If not specified, all the register file entries in a register file are caller saved, i.e. the entire register file is saved before calling a function, and restored upon returning. The user can override this by specifying the number of callee saved register file entries. This number must be between 0 and (number of entries - 1). If a register file has N entries and M are callee saved, the first N - M entries are caller saved, and the last M entries are callee saved. The first entry must be caller saved.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_SREG_CONFLICT
sect2.para: A register file name cannot be the same as a special register in the Xtensa core. This is to avoid name conflict in s/w tools such as debugger.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_STATE_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Register file and state names must be unique, to avoid name conflict in s/w tools such as debugger.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_FIELD_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Register file and field names must be unique, if the field is used in operands.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_WIDTH
sect2.para: The maximum allowed width of register file is 1024 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_REGFILE_USE_DEF
sect2.para: There are some restrictions on use/def stages on register files. The earliest use stage of a read port of a register file must be less than the maximum def stage among all write ports. For example, the following combination of use/def stages is illegal: use ( 3, 4) , def ( 1 ), where the stages are numbered from E(1) and up.
In addition, for AR register file, the earliest use stage must be 2 or less.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_COPROCESSOR_CONFLICT
sect2.para: If an instruction accesses state/register/tieports of a coprocessor, tie compiler automatically generates logic for the instruction to throw a coprocessor exception if the corresponding bit is disabled in the state CPENABLE. To do so, it adds CPENABLE as an input to the instruction and a use to the schedule. If a schedule already exists, and is shared by several instructions whose automatic CPENABLE use stage, don't match, the user is advised to break up the schedule.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHEDULE_CORE_SCHEDULE
sect2.para: Schedule name conflicts with a predefined schedule in Xtensa core.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_DUPLICATE_OPCODE
sect2.para: Opcode names in list of schedule must be unique.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_ILLEGAL_DEF_NAME
sect2.para: The def name in the schedule is not an output operand/state for any opcodes in the schedule.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_ILLEGAL_DEF_STAGE
sect2.para: Register operands and states can be written in stage 1 (E) and up. Interfaces such as VAddr and MemDataOut have fixed def stages, which are E and M respectively. TIE output queues have fixed def stage of M, and TIE lookup output has def stage as defined in the lookup.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_ILLEGAL_USE_NAME
sect2.para: The use name in the schedule is not an input operand/state for any opcodes in the schedule.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_ILLEGAL_USE_STAGE
sect2.para: Register operands and states can be read in stage 1 (E) and up. Interfaces such as MemDataIn have fixed use stage (M). TIE input queues have fixed use stage of M, import wires have a fixed use stage of E, and TIE lookup input has use stage as defined in the lookup.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_INCORRECT_STAGE

item.itemtext: VAddr : def E
MemDataIn and MemDataOut : use M and def M respectively.
TIE Queue : use M and def M for input and output queues respectively.
TIE lookup : use and def as defined in the lookup.
import wire : use E.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_INVALID
sect2.para: The schedule defined for an output cannot be achieved based on the schedule of inputs and wires in the operation or semantic. For example, in the following code, the output "d" of the instruction "LOAD.ADD" cannot be defined before the M stage because d depends on MemDataIn32, which has a use of M. The schedule with "def d 1" is therefore invalid.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_LATENCY
sect2.para: The maximum latency of an instruction is determined by the Xtensa configuration and cannot be exceeded when writing a schedule.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_MIN_DEF
sect2.para: Any register or state can be written in stage E (1) and up.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_MIN_USE
sect2.para: Any register or state can be read in stage E (1) and up.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_SHARED_FUNCTION
sect2.para: When a shared function is used multiple times in an operation/semantic, each instance of the function is scheduled in a specific cycle, since the hardware is shared. In some cases, no cycles can be found for a shared function if the number of instances exceed the maximum latency allowed for an instruction.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_UNIQUE_STAGE
sect2.para: All operands and states written in a schedule must have a unique stage for use/def. For example, "use a 1; use a 3;" is an illegal schedule since there is no unique use stage for a.

sect2.title: TIE_SCHED_USE_AFTER_DEF
sect2.para: If an instruction reads and writes the same operand/state with a use stage that is greater than the def stage, there may be a misconception that the value read is the output of the same instruction. This is not the case. All register (and state) reads happen when the instruction is issued in the register read (R) stage, and these values are piped down to the appropriate use stage. In the case when the input operand/state is being defined by another instruction in the pipeline, instead of waiting for the instruction to update the register file and then read from it, the data is forwarded from the previous instruction's output. But, there is no data forwarding within the same instruction.
This warning is not seen by default. To see it, run TIE compiler with the -warnall flag.

sect2.title: TIE_SEAMLESS_NAME_LEN
sect2.para: Mentor Graphics Seamless requires an upper limit of the length of certain identifiers. For configurations with Seamless option selected, TC reports an error if the requirement is violated.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_AMBIGUOUS_OPND_NAME
sect2.para: The semantic shares operations and references. An operation argument name is the same as an iclass operand name.

sect2.title: TIE_SEMANTIC_CORE_SEMANTIC
sect2.para: The semantic is already defined as a Xtensa core semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_SEMANTIC_DUPLICATE_OPCODE
sect2.para: The list of opcodes for a semantic must have unique opcode names.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_FALSE_DEP
sect2.para: When writing a combined semantic for multiple instructions with different inputs and outputs, it is possible to introduce an error which causes an incorrect dependency between the output of an instruction to an input to the semantic that is not an input to the instruction. This would cause incorrect functional behavior of the semantic.
If the instruction has a correct operation or reference description, running formal verification between the reference and the semantic would also point out such an error.
For example, in the following code, due to incorrect logic in the select for wire "b", the output of opcode "I1" will depend on art, which is invalid for the opcode.
Warrning: (TIE_SEM_FALSE_DEP), Semantic "sem1", output "arr" of instruction "I1" may depend on input "art" which is not in its iclass

Note that this is issued as a warning because the analysis of the body of the instruction is done with algorithms which in some rare case may generate a dependency which is not true. You are thus strongly encouraged to review the semantic to verify that there is no such dependence. If the dependence is real, it can result in incorrect hardware and faulty silicon.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_MULTIPLE_DEF
sect2.para: When combining instructions into a semantic, a common output of the instructions must be written in the same stage for all of the instructions. An output of a semantic cannot be written in different stages for different instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_MULTIPLE_USE
sect2.para: When combining instructions into a semantic, a common input of the instructions must be read in the same stage for all of the instructions. An input of a semantic cannot be read in different stages for different instructions.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_NO_DEP
sect2.para: When writing a combined semantic for multiple instructions with different inputs and outputs, it is possible to introduce an error which causes an input of an instruction to be ignored. This would cause incorrect functional behavior of the semantic.
If the instruction has a correct reference, running formal verification between the reference and the semantic would also point out this error.
For example, in the following code, due to incorrect logic in the select for wire "b", the input art of opcode "I2" will not be used to compute "arr".
Note that this is issued as a warning because the analysis of the body of the instruction is done with algorithms which in some rare case may generate a dependency which is not true.

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_OPERATION_ARG_KIND
sect2.para: When combining multiple operations into a semantic, the named arguments of all operations must map to the same type of operand. For example, in the following code, the operations "OP1" and "OP2" have different kind of operands mapped to the name "a" and therefore cannot be combined into a semantic.
Error: (TIE_SEM_OPERATION_ARG_KIND), Semantic alu, argument "a" requires different kinds of operands for operations OP1 and OP2

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_OPERATION_ARG_TYPE
sect2.para: When combining multiple operations into a semantic, the named arguments of all operations must map to the same register file. For example, in the following code, the operations "OP1" and "OP2" have different register files mapped to the name "a" and therefore cannot be combined into a semantic.
Error: (TIE_SEM_OPERATION_ARG_TYPE), Semantic alu, argument "a" requires operands that access two different register files for operations OP1 and OP2

sect2.title: TIE_SEM_OPERATION_ARG_OPNDS
sect2.para: When combining multiple operations into a semantic, the named arguments of all operations must map to the same operands. For example, in the following code, the operations "OP1" and "OP2" have different operands mapped to the name "a" and therefore cannot be combined into a semantic.

sect2.title: TIE_SHIFT_AMOUNT
sect2.para: Shift amount specified in expression will cause a larger than needed hardware. This typically happens due to expressions involving integer constants which are interpreted as 32 bit values. Example:

sect2.title: TIE_SIGNEXTEND_ERR
sect2.para: The usage of SignExtendFrom and SignExtendTo interface is wrong. The interfaces can only co-exist with MemDataIn32 interface. They can only be assigned to value 4 or less.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_ARG_DIR
sect2.para: This error is generated for reduction property statements where one of the protos, the "init", "vector", "fini" or "scalar" has an argument with mismatched directions.
The init proto should have 2 arguments, an output with the reduction type and an in with the scalar type.

The vector proto should have as many arguments as the scalar proto. The first argument should be an output with the reduction type. The second should be an in with the reduction type. The rest of the arguments should all contain either the scalar type matching the one in the scalar proto or a vector type with the appropriate vector length corresponding to the one in the scalar proto.
The fini proto should have 2 arguments. The first is an output with the scalar type. The second in an output with the reduction type.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_ARG_TYPE
sect2.para: This error is generated for reduction property statements where one of the protos, the "init", "vector", "fini" or "scalar" has an invalid argument with mismatched directions.
The init proto should have 2 arguments, an output with the reduction type and an in with the scalar type.

The vector proto should have as many arguments as the scalar proto. The first argument should be an output with the reduction type. The second should be an in with the reduction type. The rest of the arguments should all contain either the scalar type matching the one in the scalar proto or a vector type with the appropriate vector length corresponding to the one in the scalar proto.
The fini proto should have 2 arguments. The first is an output with the scalar type. The second in an output with the reduction type.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_ARG_VECTYPE
sect2.para: This error is generated for the vector proto for a reduction property statement where one of the arguments to the protos mismatches the corresponding argument to the scalar proto.
For the vector proto, after the first 2 arguments, the rest of the arguments must have the type of corresponding scalar proto type or a vector type for that type with the appropriate vector length.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_CTYPE
sect2.para: The ctype for a reduction operation must be a valid ctype.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_CTYPE_CASE
sect2.para: The ctype for a reduction operation must be a valid ctype. This message is generated if there is a ctype that almost matches the one specified.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_NUM_ARGS
sect2.para: This error is generated for reduction property statements where one of the protos, the "init", "vector", "fini" or "scalar" has an invalid number of protos.
The init proto should have 2 arguments, an output with the reduction type and an in with the scalar type.

The vector proto should have as many arguments as the scalar proto. The first argument should be an output with the reduction type. The second should be an in with the reduction type. The rest of the arguments should all contain either the scalar type matching the one in the scalar proto or a vector type with the appropriate vector length corresponding to the one in the scalar proto.
The fini proto should have 2 arguments. The first is an output with the scalar type. The second in an output with the reduction type.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMD_REDUCTION_OP
sect2.para: This error is generated for reduction property statements where the scalar proto is an intrinsic that does not allow user-reductions.
The intrinsics that are user-reducible are xt_add, xt_band, xt_bnand, xt_bnor, xt_bor, xt_bxor, xt_max, xt_min, xt_sub, xt_mpy, xt_madd, and xt_msub.

sect2.title: TIE_SIMPLE_CONSTRUCT
sect2.para: This error is only generated when you run the TIE compiler with the -chk_tiegen flag. It means that your TIE description does not fully specify all the information required to determine the opcode, operand and field encodings for all the TIE instructions.

The TIE compiler can automatically assign the encoding(s), but you are not guaranteed to always get the same encoding from one run to another. If you would like the TIE compiler to assign the encoding, you should run it without the -chk_tiegen flag. If you want to specify all the encodings yourself, you must update the TIE description to address the specific problem(s) highlighted with this error message.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_ALL_SIZED
sect2.para: The slots in a format should either be all explicitly assigned to bits or all left to the TIE compiler to assign bits. A mix is not allowed. Example:

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_COMP_WRONG_INDEX_ORDER
sect2.para: When assigning bits of a format to a slot, the order must be from:to, where from is > to. Example:

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_COMP_WRONG_INDEX_RANGE
sect2.para: When assigning bits of a format to a slot, the index must be within the range of the instruction word.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_DIFF_FORMAT
sect2.para: A slot definition must have one format name only. For example, the following is illegal
length xlen64 64 { InstBuf[3:0] == 15 }
format xl64 xlen64 { slot0, slot1 } { InstBuf[4] == 1'b0 } format ml64 xlen64 { slot0 } { InstBuf[4] == 1'b1 }

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_DIFF_SIZE
sect2.para: A slot must have the same size when defined in multiple formats. For example, the following is illegal
slot slot0 vliwa[21:0] slot slot0 vliwb[21:4]

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_MULTI_BIT
sect2.para: The same bits of the instruction word can be used only once in a slot definition, when the slot is defined as a concatenation of different bits of the format.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_NO_NOP
sect2.para: Every slot must have a NOP instruction in a multi-slot format so that the compiler can always generate a valid flix instruction. A nop is always automatically added by the TIE compiler if the encoding space allows it.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_NO_SLOT_OPCODE
sect2.para: Every slot must have a "slot_opcodes" statement to indicate what opcodes are allowed in that slot. A slot with no opcodes is not allowed. It must have NOP at the least.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_UNKNOWN_FORMAT
sect2.para: The format name in the slot definition is not a known format.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_UNUSABLE_BITS
sect2.para: Slot contains some bits that cannot be used for encoding or operands.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_OPCODE_FIELD_CONFLICT
sect2.para: Slot and field names must be unique in a case insensitive way to avoid naming conflicts in TIE compiler generated code.

sect2.title: TIE_SLOT_OPCODES_SLOT_UNDEFINED
sect2.para: The slot name in the slot_opcodes definition is not a known slot.

sect2.title: TIE_SREG_NAME_CONFLICT
sect2.para: The user register specified will have a name conflict with an existing user register. For example, a user register cannot be named "PS" because there is a special register "PS" in the Xtensa core.

sect2.title: TIE_SREG_OPCODE_USED
sect2.para: The user register specified will generate opcodes that will have a name conflict with an existing user register.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_ALREADY_MAPPED
sect2.para: The same state cannot be mapped to multiple user registers, if a user register is manually written for a state, it cannot have the add_read_write option as well.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_CORE_STATE
sect2.para: A Xtensa core state with the same name is defined. State names must be unique in a case-insensitive way.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_EXPORT_INIT
sect2.para: All export states must have a initial value. This is the value of the state when Xtensa comes out of reset. If no initial value is assigned, the state value is unknown until it is written in the program.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_INIT_WIDTH
sect2.para: The width of state initialization value need to be within the state width. In the case that the state width is exceeded, the upper bits are ignored.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_MAX_WIDTH
sect2.para: Maximum width of a state is 1024 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_MULTIPLE_MAP
sect2.para: The same bits of a state cannot be mapped to multiple user registers.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_NO_DEF
sect2.para: There are no writes to the state from any instruction. Note that "add_read_write" automatically generates "RUR/WUR" instructions that read and write the state.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_NO_UREG_MAP
sect2.para: A state has to be fully mapped to user-registers if it belongs to a coprocessor, so that the state can be saved and restored upon coprocessor exception and context switch.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_NO_USE
sect2.para: There are no reads from the state from any instruction. Note that "add_read_write" automatically generates "RUR/WUR" instructions that read and write the state.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_SHARED_OR
sect2.para: The following limitations are imposed on states with "shared_or" attributes: 1. The states cannot be killed. If state value is conditionally assigned, set the state direction as inout and assign the input value instead. 2. The states cannot appear in the instructions containing memory, import wire, queue, or lookup interfaces.

sect2.title: TIE_STATE_USE_DEF
sect2.para: The earliest use stage of a state must be less than on equal to the maximum def stage of the state, to ensure correct implementation.

sect2.title: TIE_SUBFIELD_NOT_DEFINED
sect2.para: If a field is defined as a concatenation of other subfields, all the subfields must be defined.

sect2.title: TIE_SUBSCRIPT
sect2.para: Illegal subscript. Legal subscript syntax is name[from:to] where :

item.itemtext: both from and to are within the bounds of the size of the variable, i.e. >=0 and <= size - 1.
from >= to

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_CORE_TABLE
sect2.para: The table name is already defined in the Xtensa core.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_FIELD_CONFLICT
sect2.para: The table name conflicts with a field name. Table names must be unique.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_ILLEGAL_WIDTH
sect2.para: The width of a table entry must be > 0 and <= 32 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_ILLEGAL_ENTRY
sect2.para: The entry in the table uses more than 32 bits.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_NUM_ELEMENTS
sect2.para: The number of elements in the table is larger than the size of the table. Note that if the table has less elements than the size, it is zero padded.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_USE
sect2.para: A table can be indexed with a single index only. TABLE[from:to] is ambiguous.

sect2.title: TIE_TABLE_VALUE
sect2.para: The entry value in the table does not fit in the width of the table.

sect2.title: TIE_TIEGEN
sect2.para: TIE compiler failed to generate the correct encoding for operations and flix formats. This is usually accompanied by a detailed message about the specific error cause.

sect2.title: TIE_PORT_PROTECT
sect2.para: If the Xtensa configuration has an MMU, all tieports must have some protection implemented. This is done by putting every tieport in a coprocessor such that the the coprocessors can be disabled for certain tasks to achieve some protection.

sect2.title: TIE_TPP_EXEC_FAIL
sect2.para: Could not run the TIE perl preprocessor.

sect2.title: TIE_UNDERUTILIZED_RANGE
sect2.para: The immediate range specified is using bits that are not all utilized.

sect2.title: TIE_UNIMPLEMENTABLE_RANGE
sect2.para: The immediate range specified cannot be efficiently implemented.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NAME
sect2.para: User registers should be defined with names only. Numbers are not needed.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NAME_ALLOC
sect2.para: The user register name specified will generate opcodes that conflict with an existing operation or another user register.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NAME_ALREADY_USED
sect2.para: The user register name specified is already used.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NAME_CONFLICT
sect2.para: The user register name specified will conflict with another name.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NAME_ILLEGAL
sect2.para: User register names of the form "UR[number]" should not be used.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NO_MAP
sect2.para: No state mapped to the user register.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NO_STATE
sect2.para: The state name in the user register definition does not exist.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NUMBER
sect2.para: User TIE should use user register numbers from 0-223. Note that user registers should be written with name only so that TIE compiler can automatically assign an appropriate number.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NUMBER_ALLOC
sect2.para: TIE compiler could not allocate a user register number because all valid numbers are used.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_NUM_ALREADY_USED
sect2.para: The user register number specified is already used. Note that user registers should be written with name only so that TIE compiler can automatically assign an appropriate number.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_OPCODE_USED
sect2.para: The RUR/WUR opcode is already defined manually, so TIE compiler cannot generate these automatically.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_SIZE
sect2.para: A user register can map only 32 bits of a state. Wider states should be mapped to multiple user registers. Note that TIE compiler automatically generates user registers for all bits of a state with the "add_read_write" option.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_STATE_BITS
sect2.para: User register maps state bits outside the valid range, must be >=0 and <= state width - 1.

sect2.title: TIE_UREG_STATE_NAME_CONFLICT
sect2.para: A user register cannot have the same name as a state unless it has a one to one mapping from a state. A user register that maps only a few bits of a state, or maps multiple states must be named differently. This is to avoid naming confusion in the debugger.

sect2.title: TIE_WIRE_CYCLIC_DEP
sect2.para: The wire in the semantic depends on itself. For example,
Error: (TIE_WIRE_CYCLIC_DEP), The declared wires in the assignment block have cyclic dependency involving xx ,yy

sect2.title: TIE_WIRE_DECL
sect2.para: Illegal wire declaration. Wires should be declared as [from:to] where both "from" and "to" are >=0 and from is greater than to.

sect2.title: TIE_XCC_MAX_NUM
sect2.para: XCC requires that the total number of states, register files, and ports is less than 1024. The total number of ports includes ports generated from TIE queues (3 ports per queue), import wires (1 port), export states (1 port) and TIE lookup (2 ports per lookup without Rdy, and 3 with Rdy).

sect2.title: TIE_XTENSA_CONFIG
sect2.para: This feature is not supported by the base Xtensa core used.
